Posts.Content: Hi Fairwind, I am 55 and my last PCA reading in April was 6.7, no idea what it would be now. Everything that I have read would indicate that I have been put into a no win situation. Trying to hold on to hope but also prepare myself for what I believe will be a failed surgery. Ronald
Posts.Title: Update with pathology report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi Ronald, I also was a stage T2C. This means that the cancer, based on your biopsy report, is believed to still be confined to the prostate. Keep in mind that even the most aggressive prostate cancer is curable if treated in time. It is good news that there seems to be no extraprostatic spread. Hopefully the same goes for the seminal vesicles and nearby lymph nodes. If this all should be true, you would very possibly be looking at a cure. Also keep in mind that they usually do not recommend surgery unless they believe a cure is very possible. If you go through with surgery as your preferred treatment, it is extremely important that your surgeon will have previously performed at least 500-600 of whichever type of surgery you opt for (open method or robotic). Could be that some follow-up radiation treatments could be necessary after the surgery, depending on what the pathologist finds in his post-op exam of the prostate and other tissues. If weight is a major concern, it is also possible that external beam radiation, or radioactive seeding, might be a better course of action for you. It probably would be a good idea to speak with both a surgeon and a radiation oncologist to get the pros and cons from both sides. In any event, I can see lots of hope for you to have a successful treatment in whatever course you choose. Good luck! Chuck Hi Chuck, Thanks for the words of encouragement. You said that even the most aggresive cancer can be cured if treated in time. Theres my problem. I cannot find anything to back up waiting this length of time with a Gleason 8 cancer. By reading all the posts here, it would seem that the vast majority go from diagnosis to treatment in 60 to 90 days. I am now approaching 250 days. Can cancer stay confined for that length of time without becoming worse? Wondering if I had another biopsy, PCA test, CT scan, bone scan, if I would receive the same prognosis that I received last spring? I had originally asked back last spring to have radioactive seeding. I was told that wasn't an option due to the severity of the cancer. Later in the summer I asked that I have external beam radiation. That was denied as well. I was told that the long term side effects were to bad for my age. We don't have much of an option to get different opinions around here. There is only 1 CancerCare Centre which deals with everyone who gets cancer.
Posts.Title: Update with pathology report

Posts.Content: Hi Chuck, I was just told today that the surgery will be on Dec 21. I guess I will just have to hope that there has been no spread of the cancer. I will log in again after surgery and postop pathology results to let you all know if waiting this long was a mistake. Ronald

Posts.Title: Update with pathology report

Posts.Content: Hi Guys..... following up to my post on Nov 19/12, I would like to add my pathology report findings and ask for your opinions. the report showed that 7 out of 12 core were positive for PC; Left lateral base; Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+4=8/10, involves 25% of the core, 4mm. Left lateral mid; Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+4=8/10, involves 15% of the core, in two foci. Left lateral apex; Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+4=8/10, involves 75% of the core, 10mm. Right medial base; Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+4=8/10, involves 5% of the core. Left medial base; Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+4=8/10, involves 40% of the core, 6mm. Left medial mid; Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+4=8/10, involves 60% of the core, 9mm. Left medial apex; Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+4=8/10, involves 50% of the core, 5mm. There was no evidence of extra prostatic spread. I am a Gleason 8, Stage T2C. Diagnosed in April, currently waiting for surgery date!!! (In Canada) Very worried that after waiting 8 months that surgery will fail. Also, has anyone heard of anyone having to have a tummy tuck or panniculectomy along with the pc surgery? My cancer surgeon is having a plastic surgeon perform this along with him. Says this will allow him better access, as I am a big guy Thanks, Ronald

Posts.Title: Update with pathology report

Posts.Content: Hi, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer back in April 2012. My psa was 6.7 and my Gleason score is 4+4=8 Was told stage is T2c I had a ct and bone scan in Aug which was clear. It is now almost 7 months and I still don't have a surgery date. Been told it would be before end of year. My age is 55 Very concerned this has taken too long to address and I will not have good outcome. Welcome comments
Posts.Title: New member looking for advice and support

Posts.Content: Thanks. I am in Canada. Unfortunately, the prostate cancer centre in my city just received a "F" grade in service delivery. My experience so far has been a very frustrating one.
Posts.Title: New member looking for advice and support

Posts.Content: Looks like BC has their act together better than us here in Manitoba. I wasn't told that HRT or radiation were options. Was advised that only surgery would be the best course of action. Didn't think I would have to wait this long though. I will be surprised if the cancer is still contained to the prostate once I finally do have the surgery. Regional Health Authority here had a conference last week where they stated their goal was to address service delivery and ensure that the time from diagnosis to treatment was 60 days. This appears to follow what occures in the US.
Posts.Title: New member looking for advice and support

Posts.Content: Hi, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer back in April 2012. My psa was 6.7 and my Gleason score is 4+4=8 Was told stage is T2c I had a ct and bone scan in Aug which was clear. Posts.Title: New member looking for advice and support

Posts.Content: Thanks Dave. No other options except to follow the system. Doctor did mention HRT while I waited then changed his mind. Said it wouldn't make that much difference. (?) Other than the ct and bone scans in Aug, no one is checking or monitoring anything. Around here it's hurry up and wait!
Posts.Title: New member looking for advice and support

Posts.Content: Thanks for the support. i have noticed that must U.S. members go from diagnosis to surgery in 60 days. Is there a medical reason for this timelyness. I am very worried that having waited for 7 months it is too late to think the cancer will still be confined. As for choices; I originally went to the Doc with the intent of having radiation, but after a verbal barrage of reasons why that was not a good choice, I signed a consent for surgery. He said that radiation at my age would lead to a whole bunch of complications down the road in about 15 years. He was quite adament about it and quite convincing.
